Award.AwardTitle: RAPID: Trajectories of Social Vulnerability among Houston Area Households: A Pre- and Post-event Study of Hurricane Harvey

Division.LongName: Div Of Civil, Mechanical, & Manufact Inn

Award.AbstractNarration:
Hurricane Harvey hit the Houston, Texas, metropolitan area on 25 August, 2017 and caused unprecedented damage. As of 4 September, 2017, estimates indicate that over 156,000 homes were destroyed and at least 60 people died. Preliminary loss estimates suggest that impacts could well exceed $100 billion, making Harvey the costliest disaster in U.S. history. This project examines underlying factors influencing Hurricane Harvey-induced flood experiences, impacts, and short-term recovery across Houston area households. The project leverages baseline data collected before Hurricane Harvey from a representative sample of Houston area households regarding their vulnerability to hurricanes and flooding, and involves the rapid collection of post-Harvey survey data from those same households. By clarifying how pre-event factors shape households' experiences, impacts, and short-term recovery during and immediately following Hurricane Harvey, the project provides new insights into determinants of community vulnerability versus resilience. As was demonstrated during Hurricane Harvey, people's decision making plays a critical role in the vulnerability of a communities' built environment when subjected to extreme events. Through the collection and examination of a pre- and post-event survey data from the same sample of households, this research project advances our knowledge of the role of underlying social vulnerability in community resilience and recovery during and immediately following large-scale disasters.

The research objective of this project is to collect data in Houston following Hurricane Harvey to further our understanding of how social vulnerability manifests in flood experiences, impacts, and short-term recovery. The project leverages survey data collected from 600 randomly selected Houston area households in 2012, and involves re-surveying them regarding their Hurricane Harvey-induced flood experiences, impacts, and short-term recovery (in October 2017). Based on updated contact information, the project will collect a second wave of survey data from households still residing in the Houston area at the time of Hurricane Harvey. With this survey data, multivariate statistical models will be used to predict flood experiences, impacts, and short-term recovery across study households using explanatory variables derived from the 2012 and 2017 surveys.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Research prior to Hurricane Harvey has shown that neighborhoods in the Greater Houston metro area with higher proportions of minorities and lower socioeconomic status (SES) were disproportionately exposed to environmental hazards like air pollution and potential flooding. Prior research on social vulnerability to disasters reveals that socially disadvantaged groups generally have reduced capabilities to prepare for, respond to, and recover from disasters. This project examined social vulnerability in terms of flood experiences, impacts, and short-term recovery following Hurricane Harvey in Greater Houston. It relied on the collection of social survey data in 2017 from 439 Greater Houston households, including 71 households who also completed a separate 2012 survey (administered as part of NSF Award Number 1129984) that examined air pollution and flooding.

 

In terms of intellectual merit, the project clarified important dimensions of social vulnerability with respect to Hurricane Harvey exposures, health impacts, and short-term recovery. Based on the survey sample of Greater Houston households, we found that greater pre-event flood hazard mitigation was associated with fewer physical health problems, adverse event experiences, lower post-traumatic stress (PTS), and faster recovery. In addition, findings indicate that the extent of Hurricane Harvey-induced flooding around homes and across neighborhoods was distributed inequitably, indicating social disparities in exposures. Racial/ethnic minority households and neighborhoods with higher minority composition experienced more extensive flooding than white households and neighborhoods with higher white composition; lower SES households and neighborhoods also experienced more extensive flooding than higher SES households and neighborhoods; and neighborhoods with higher (vs. lower) proportions of disabled residents experienced more extensive flooding. Additionally, we found that neighborhoods proximate to petrochemical facilities reporting accidental hazardous chemical releases due to Hurricane Harvey had disproportionately high concentrations of residents who were African American, Hispanic, in poverty, disabled, or under 15 years of age. Using the survey sample, we also assessed of Hurricane Harvey-related health disparities, which revealed that PTS had disproportionate impacts on African Americans and those experiencing post-Harvey unemployment, and that healthcare access was constrained for those experiencing post-Harvey unemployment and those with disabilities. In a separate analysis of the survey data focused on adverse event experiences and short-term recovery of Greater Houstonians after Hurricane Harvey, we found that racial/ethnic minorities experienced significantly more unmet needs following the disaster than non-Hispanic whites.

 

In terms of broader impacts, project outcomes include enhanced knowledge of social vulnerabilities among Greater Houston households in terms of Hurricane Harvey exposures, health outcomes, and short-term recovery, as well as increased participation of individuals from underrepresented backgrounds in hazards research. Findings from the project have been circulated via multiple outlets. Analyses provided the basis for 4 published articles in scholarly journals, including the American Journal of Public Health, Social Science & Medicine, Environmental Research, and Disasters (with 4 additional manuscripts under review at the time of reporting); 1 book chapter in an edited volume; and 12 presentations at local and national conferences and invited events. Education and research training opportunities were provided to graduate and undergraduate students—all of whom are from traditionally underrepresented backgrounds. The project integrated training of 2 doctoral students and 2 undergraduate students, and it provides the basis for 1 doctoral dissertation and 2 undergraduate research experiences. Student trainees are lead authors on 6 project manuscripts and 6 project presentations. All manuscripts include at least 1 student trainee as coauthor and all but 1 presentation included student trainees as coauthors. All student trainees are currently on track to graduate from their respective degree programs.
